Child's Pose (Balasana) primarily stretches the spine, hips, and thighs, working muscles like the lower back (erector spinae), glutes, hip flexors, lats, and shoulders, while providing a restorative and calming forward fold that activates the parasympathetic nervous system for relaxation, improving mobility and relieving tension. Its movement pattern involves spinal flexion and hip flexion, creating a gentle decompression. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  
Muscles Worked & Stretched 

• Lower Back (Erector Spinae): Gently stretches and decompresses the lumbar spine. 
• Glutes (Buttocks): Stretches the gluteal muscles, relieving hip tension. 
• Hip Flexors: Stretches the front of the thighs. 
• Shoulders (Teres Major, Latissimus Dorsi): Stretches when arms are extended forward, improving mobility. 
• Thighs/Quads: Stretches the front of the thighs. 
• Ankles & Feet: Mild stretch from the tucked position. 
• Obliques & Core: Gentle engagement supports spinal movement. [1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 9]  

Movement Pattern & Benefits 

• Type: A forward fold and restorative pose. 
• Spinal Movement: Lower spine flexes (rounds), upper spine extends slightly, promoting decompression. 
• Hip Movement: Hip flexion (folding hips towards thighs). 
• Nervous System: Stimulates the vagus nerve through forehead support and deep breathing, activating the relaxation response (parasympathetic nervous system). 
• Purpose: Rest, stress relief, back pain relief, improved mobility, and a moment to reset. [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10, 11]
